00028 #include "qf_pkg.h"
00029 /* #include "qassert.h" */
00030 
00031 /* Q_DEFINE_THIS_MODULE(qf_tick) */
00032 
00039 /*..........................................................................*/
00040 void QF_tick(void) {                                          /* see NOTE01 */
00041     QTimeEvt *t;
00042     QF_INT_LOCK_KEY_
00043 
00044     QF_INT_LOCK_();
00045 
00046     QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TICK, (void *)0, (void *)0)
00047         QS_TEC_(++QS_tickCtr_);                         /* the tick counter */
00048     QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00049 
00050     t = QF_timeEvtListHead_;
00051     while (t != (QTimeEvt *)0) {
00052         --t->ctr;
00053         if (t->ctr == (QTimeEvtCtr)0) {     /* is time evt about to expire? */
00054             if (t->interval != (QTimeEvtCtr)0) { /* is it periodic timeout? */
00055                 t->ctr = t->interval;               /* rearm the time event */
00056             }
00057             else { /* one-shot timeout, disarm by removing it from the list */
00058                 if (t == QF_timeEvtListHead_) {
00059                     QF_timeEvtListHead_ = t->next;
00060                 }
00061                 else {
00062                     if (t->next != (QTimeEvt *)0) {  /* not the last event? */
00063                         t->next->prev = t->prev;
00064                     }
00065                     t->prev->next = t->next;
00066                 }
00067                 t->prev = (QTimeEvt *)0;         /* mark the event disarmed */
00068 
00069                 QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TIMEEVT_AUTO_DISARM, QS_teObj_, t)
00070                     QS_OBJ_(t);                   /* this time event object */
00071                     QS_OBJ_(t->act);                   /* the active object */
00072                 QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00073             }
00074 
00075             QS_BEGIN_NOLOCK_(QS_QF_TIMEEVT_POST, QS_teObj_, t)
00076                 QS_TIME_();                                    /* timestamp */
00077                 QS_OBJ_(t);                        /* the time event object */
00078                 QS_SIG_(t->super.sig);         /* signal of this time event */
00079                 QS_OBJ_(t->act);                       /* the active object */
00080             QS_END_NOLOCK_()
00081 
00082             QF_INT_UNLOCK_();/* unlock interrupts before calling QF service */
00083 
00084                /* postFIFO() asserts internally that the event was accepted */
00085             QActive_postFIFO(t->act, (QEvent *)t);
00086         }
00087         else {
00088             static uint8_t volatile dummy;
00089             QF_INT_UNLOCK_();
00090             dummy = (uint8_t)0;   /* execute a few instructions, see NOTE02 */
00091         }
00092 
00093         QF_INT_LOCK_();        /* lock interrupts again to advance the link */
00094         t = t->next;
00095     }
00096     QF_INT_UNLOCK_();
00097 }
00098 
00099 /*****************************************************************************
00100 * NOTE01:
00101 * QF_tick() must always run to completion and never preempt itself.
00102 * In particular, if QF_tick() runs in an ISR, the ISR is not allowed to
00103 * preempt itself. Also, QF_tick() should not be called from two different
00104 * ISRs, which potentially could preempt each other.
00105 *
00106 * NOTE02:
00107 * On many CPUs, the interrupt unlocking takes only effect on the next
00108 * machine instruction, which happens to be here another interrupt lock.
00109 * The assignment of a volatile variable requires a few instructions, which
00110 * the compiler cannot optimize away. This ensures that the interrupts get
00111 * actually unlocked, so that the interrupt latency stays low.
00112 */
